oai_dc:dc.dc:title: .69 'buck and ball cartridge' from Fort Sanders
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Documented buck and ball cartridge from Confederate lines at Fort Sanders. Paper-wrapped, these cartridges contained a powder charge and the lead projectiles. Buck and ball ammunition was designed for smoothbore muskets and got its name from the fact that one cartridge contained one .69 caliber ball and three .30 caliber buckshot. This type of ammunition when fired at a compact formation could be devastating. Fort Sanders was part of the Federal defenses of Knoxville and was atttacked in November 1863.
